newsitem.title: USA: First Chicago sees positive credit card signs.
newsitem.headline: First Chicago sees positive credit card signs.

text.p: First Chicago NBD Corp said Monday it saw some positive signs of credit quality in its credit card portfolio, which had deteriorated in previous months.

"Actions taken last year to tighten credit standards and collection processes are starting to show up in key trend indicators," Robert Rosholt, chief financial officer, said in comments to investors Monday.

The 30-day delinquency dropped to 4.3 percent in the second quarter from 4.4 percent in the first quarter and the charge-off level was $326 million, essentially flat from the previous quarter, he said.
But Rosholt also tempered the improvement with caution.
"It's still too early to call a peak as we continue to closely monitor trends in bankruptcy losses, which account for over 40 percent of the chargeoffs," Rosholt said.
Commercial credit quality continues strong, a trend the bank expects will continue in the near future, Rosholt said.

First Chicago on Monday reported net income of $378 million or $1.20 a fully diluted share for the second quarter compared to $361 million or $1.09 a share a year ago, in line with the consensus forecast according to First Call.
First Chicago shares were up 13/16 at 63-13/16 Monday.
